questions.text: A 55 yr old man underwent an operation for lipoma. 11 months after surgery he felt severe itching and burning on the operated site where a scar is formed which is limited to the wound boundary. What is the nature of this lesion
A 55 yr old male presented to OPD with fever, wtloss, fatigue and pallor. CBC shows: Hb-9gm/di TLC-17000/cmm Platelet count-1,60,000/cmm Myeloid blasts <11% • Basophil - 4% Most probable diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Increased TLC count with basophiLia is sign for CML.also myeloblast is less then 20% which goes against AML

questions.text: Mr V, 25 yr old male is diagnosed with a testicular tumor. Which on histopathology was found be OCT-4 positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tumor markers for seminoma- B-B HCG P-PLAP L-LDH MOLECULAR MARKERS FOR SEMINOMA OCT3-4 NANOG KIT

questions.text: Gene mutation seen in hemochromatosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) GENE MUTATION HFE-Hemochromatosis(adult type) HJV-hemochromatosis(juvenile type) SERPINA-alpha 1 AT deficiency ATP7B-WILSON ds

questions.text: A 30 year old female presents with a history suggestive of chronic liver disease. Liver biopsy shows hepatocytes with ground glass appearance. Comment on the diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It is a histological hallmark of chronic hepatitis B virus infection and contains surface antigens in the proliferated endoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: A couple is trying to have a child for the past 2 year, and after multiple unsuccessful trials they went for respective examination. Investigation of female came out to be absolutely normal but male shows presence of gynecomastia, small testis and scanty pubic hairs. He had a history of antisocial behavior during school days. most probably he has:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The key words are gynecomastia with features of hypogonadism like small testis and scanty pubic hair in a male patient showing antisocial behavior. This is seen in Klinefelter syndrome. • Option A presents with idiopathic hypercalcemia and supravalvular aortic stenosis. • Option B looks like Turner syndrome and has pulmonic stenosis. • Option D has tall person with arm span > height and aortic dissection.

questions.text: All are true about arterial thromboss: EXCEPT?
Identify the image below
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The image shows small round cells with Hyperchromatic nuclei surrounding a clear lumen and are called Flexner-Wintersteiner Rosettes.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with low backache. X-ray LS spine shows osteoblastic changes. what is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Carcinoma prostate • The presence of osteoblastic changes in IS spine indicates metastasis from carcinoma prostrate. • Option A has bony lytic lesions. Option B shows focal reduction in joint space with development of gibbus.Option D also has lytic lesions and is ruled out.

questions.text: A boy presents in the emergency because of development of allergy due to pollen inhalation. Which of the following cells is important in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) HELPER T CELLS

questions.text: Owl eye appearance of cells in urine microscopic examination of post kidney transplant patient is a feature of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CMV Owl eye appearance is seen in infected kidney tubular cells due to CMV and leads to graft failure. The prominent intranuclear basophilic inclusions spanning one half of nuclear diameter are usually set off from the nuclear membrane by a clear halo.

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with a condition due to a DNA repair gene defect. He is having mottled hyperpigmentation on the skin and high risk for development skin cancers as per the physician. Which of the following is a likely enzyme defect in the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mottled hyperpigmentation on the skin and high risk for development skin cancers is sign of XERODERMA PIGMENTOSA which occur due to nucleotide excision repair defect. The pattern of inheritance in Xeroderma pigmentosum is AR and gene involved is XPA on chromosome 9922. • These patients can develop SCC and melanoma. • Option A is related to premature aging in Werner syndrome • Option C is related to ataxia telangiectasia • Option D is related to Colon cancer.

questions.text: A child presented with thymic hypoplasia, decreased immunity and hypocalcemia. He also has tetralogy of fallot. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Digeorge syndrome C-CONGENITAL HEART DEFECTS A-ABNORMAL FACIES T-THYMIC HYPOPLAISA C-CLEFT LIP/PALATE H-HYPOCALCEMIA 22-CHR 22 TB-TBX1 Pateints • Hypocalcemia indicates parathyroid gland hypoplasia.The combination of parathyroid gland and thymic hypoplasia indicates Di-George syndrome. • It is a defect of pharyngeal pouch system and is caused by heterozygous chromosomal deletion at 22q11.2. • Co-truncal cardiac abnormality seen is TOF. • SCID occurs due to adenosine deaminase defect that result in defective T cell function. • Bruton agammaglobulinemia/ X-linked agammaglobu-linemia is an inherited immunodeficiency disorder. It is characterized by the absence of mature B cells which in turn leads to severe antibody deficiency and recurrent infections.

questions.text: A child presents with rash on lower limb. He also complains of abdominal pain and joint pain, Presence of hematuria is also been documented. Platelet count not reduced. Whats the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) H-HEMATURIA S-SKIN RASH P-PAPLAPBLE PURPURA A-ARTHRITIS/ABDOMINAL PAIN

questions.text: Macrocytic anemia will be seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) MACROCYTIC ANAEMIA ARE OF 2 TYPES-MEGALOBLASTIC(B9,B12 DEFEICIENCY) AND NON MEGALOBLASTIC WHICH CAN BE REMEMBERED AS L-LIVER DS D-DARU(ALCOHOL) H-HYPOTHYROIDISM

choices.text: It is caused by deficiency of complement proteins
It is more common in females
It is an autosomal dominant disorder

questions.text: All of the following are true in respect of angioneurotic edema; Except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Angio-neurotic edema is a localized nonpitting edema involving deeper layers of the skin and subcutaneous tissue.?It is an autosomal dominant clinical condition caused by deficiency of C1 inhibitor protein (a complement regulatory protein) and associated with elevated levels of bradykinin. It is more common in females. • Diagnosis of hereditary angioedema is suggested by the presence of lack of pruritus and urticarial lesions, prominence of recurrent gastrointestinal attacks of colic and episodes of laryngeal edema. The levels of complement proteins C1 is normal but levels of C2 and C4 are depleted. • Danazol is the drug which can be used for hereditary angioedema.

questions.text: which of the following subtype of breast caner has best prognosis>
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) TYPE A HAS BEST PROGNOSIS TYPE D HAS WORST PROGNOSIS

questions.text: A middle-aged lady presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. Her intestinal biopsy demonstrated villous atrophy and serum has presence of anti- TTG antiboidies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in her?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Celiac sprue • The presence of anti-Tissue transglutaminase antibodies and villous atrophy indicates celiac sprue. It occurs due to allergy to gluten/gliadin component of cereals like barley. Rye, oats and wheat. • Option B occurs due to recurrent infection with gram negative organisms. Option C occurs with intracellular bacteria called as Tropheryma whipelli. Option D is associated with p-ANCA

questions.text: Supra-Vital staining is used for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Heinz bodies • Supravital staining is used for RBC inclusions that are not well visualized with Romanowsky dyes. • Heinz bodies appear as small round inclusions within the red cell body in case of G6PD deficiency and are visualized more clearly with supravital staining (e.g., with new methylene blue, crystal violet or bromocresol green).

questions.text: An 83 year old man shows presence of perinuclear pigment in the cardiac muscle fibers. what is the nature of pigment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lipofuscin/Lipochrome is the wear and tear pigment that is composed of polymers of lipids and phospholipids complexed with protein. It is derived via lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of intracellular membrane. It is a telltale sign of free radical injury and lipid peroxidation. It is seen in cells undergoing slow and regressive changes in the liver and heart of aging patients or patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia

questions.text: A 50 year old man presented with gum bleeding and fatigue. His peripheral smear shows marked leukocytosis with 70% cells showing MPO. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) AML The bone marrow aspiration with more than 30% MPO positive immature cells points to acute leukemia with myeloid origin. MPO is the hallmark enzyme of myeloid lineage and can be detected by cytochemical staining, immunohistochemistry or flow cytometry. • Option A presents with massive splenomegaly with FISH showing t(9:22) translocation. • Option C presents with cervical lymphadenopathy with autoimmune hemolvtic anemia. • Option D presents in children with hepatosplenomegaly and lymphoblasts and Immunophenotyping shows terminal deoxynucleotidy] transferase (IT) positivity.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mode of inheritance in a patient suffering from Red green colour blindness?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) X LINKED RECESSIVE EXAMPLES- COME-COLOUR BLINDNESS FOR-FABRY DISEASE C-CGD H-HEMOPHILIA A-AGAMMAGLOBULINEMIA W-WISKOTT ALDRICH SYNDROME A-ALBINISM L-LYSCH NYHAN SYNDROME

questions.text: Which of the following tumor is not a example of mixed tumors?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Teratoma is a germ cell tumor that is derived from all the three germ layers. It contains immature or fully formed tissue, including teeth, hair, bone and muscle. • Option D is presence of normal tissue at an abnormal site like Meckel diverticulum or chocolate cyst of ovary in endometriosis.

questions.text: Pattern of inheritance seen with a disease inherited from grandmother to father and then father to his son.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) AD Since all the three generations are affected irrespective of gender it points to autosomal dominant disorder. The point against XLR is that grandmother is also affected. In XLR females are not affected and are carriers.

questions.text: Chicken fat appearance is seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Postmortem clots Postmortem clots may have a yellow appearance at upper end and red at the lower. These are sometimes called "chicken fat" clots. The surface is still shiny and smooth indicating a clot, not a thrombus. The yellow portion represents clotted plasma and the red cells have settled out and clotted at the bottom of the clot.

questions.text: Neural tube defect shows which pattern of inheritance?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Multifactorial Neural tube defects account for the largest proportion of congenital anomalies of the CNS and result from failure of the neural tube to close spontaneously between the 3rd and 4th week of in utero development. Although the precise cause of NTDs remains unknown, evidence suggests that many factors, including hyperthermia, evidence suggests that many factors, including hyperthermia, drugs (valproic acid), malnutition, low red cell folate levels, chemicals, maternal obesity or diabetes, and genetic determinants (mutations in folate-responsive or folate-dependent enzyme pathways) can adversely affect normal development of the CNS from the time of conception. OTHER MULTIFACTORIAL DISORDERS H-HTN N-NEURAL TUBE DEFECTS D-DM C-CLEFT LIP/PALATE C.CONGENITAL HEART DEFECTS

questions.text: A 60 year old man present with 2 month history of weakness and pallor. Per adbomen shows moderate splenomegaly. Peripheral blood shows Hb= 10gm/dl, leukocytosis and platelet 3 lac/cu. mm. P. smear shows metamyelocytes 15%, promyeloblasts 30%, Myeloblast 45%. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CML AML has maturational arrest and only myeloblasts are found in bone marrow and peripheral smear. The presence of metamyelocytes 15%, Promyeloblasts 30%, Myeloblast 45% indicates shift to left and is a feature of CML. ALL and CLL are ruled out as they would have lymphoblasts in circulation.

questions.text: 65 year old man presents with hypercalcemia and deranged KFT. Workup shows HB is low, TIC is elevated and X-ray skull shows multiple lytic lessions. Comment on diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Multiple myeloma • Features of CRAB like HyperCalcemia, Renal failure, Anemia and Bony lytic lesions point to diagnosis as Multiple myeloma. • Option A leads to hypercalcemia and lytic lesions but does not have renal failure • Option C presents with features of hyperthyroidism and option D leads to metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Testing for which of the following infections is not done before giving blood transfusion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) INFECTIONS TO BE SCREENED BEFOR BLOOD TRANSFUSIOn HIV HEP B HEP C MALARIA SYPHILLIS Hep a spreads by feco oral route.

questions.text: Cells responsible for chronic graft rejection are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) T cells • Histopathological change of interstitial fibrosis, tubular atrophy and arteritis is seen in Chronic allograft rejection • T cells are central in the rejection of grafts. The rejection reaction consists of the sensitization stage and the effector stage. • Sensitization stage: CD4 and CD8 T cells, via their T-cell receptors, recognize the allo-antigens expressed on the cells of the foreign graft • Effector stage: CD4-positive T cells initiate macrophage-mediated delayed type hypersensitivity responses and provide help to B cells for antibody production. 31.ANS-B Child with features of nephritic syndrome like cola colour urine,hematuria most probable dx would be PSGN/APGN(Acute proliferative GN)

questions.text: A mother brought her 10 yr hypertensive child to the ER with complains of facial edema, cola colored urine, On further evaluation the child was found to be hypertensive. Urine examination revealed hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The clinical findings of Nephritic syndrome ( hematuria and red cell casts) seen in this child is most likely due to Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.(PSGN) The pathogenesis involves circulating antibodies elicited by streptococcal antigens reacting with normal glomerular antigens and complement activation by directly deposited streptococcal antigens causing the immunologic injury. -Decrease in the serum complement levels -ASO tites is increased .

questions.text: A 24 year old female came to the OPD with malar rash. On further investigations she was found to be positive for Anti-Smith antibody. what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) SLE • Anti-Smith antibody is specific for diagnosis of SLE. Presence of malar rash that worsens on sunlight exposure is a key feature. The arthritis involves knee joint. • Option B has anti Scl-70/ Anti-topoisomerase Antibody. Option D has Anti centromere antibody. Option D is diagnosed with MRI guided muscle biopsy and elevated CPK-MM levels.

questions.text: A 25 year old male went for trekking. He had a bee sting which resulted in edema and redness on face. What is the type of antibody responsible for this type of reaction?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) IgE Bee sting results in release of histamine and can cause IgE mediated anaphylaxis. This explains the redness on face and difficulty in breathing in this patient.

questions.text: Mr. X who is a masson cutter presented with chest tightness and respiratory difficulty. He was TB positive. Most probable disease related to this finding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Silicosis patients are prone to developing tuberculosis in a condition called silico-tuberculosis. Silica causes pulmonary alveolar macrophage dysfunction and hence patients with Silicosis have a higher risk of developing lung infections from organisms like M.Tuberculosis , atypical mycobacteria and fungi .

questions.text: Identify the pattern of inheritance from the pedigree chart shown below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Autosomal dominant In the given pedigree, the trait is passed onto males and female equally and presenting in every generation, hence it is Autosomal dominant. Hence, it is not X-linked recessive. The female is not transmitting to all the children, hence it is not mitochondrial. Also, the trait is present in every generation and is not skipping generations, hence it is not autosomal recessive.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is responsible for the destruction of bacterial foreign bodies in liver sinusoids.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Kupffer cells Kupffer cells are specialised macrophages of the liver responsible for the destruction of bacterial foreign bodies. These cells are present in the Space of Disse. They are responsible for removing cellular and microbial debris from the circulation.

questions.text: The given inclusions bodies are characteristic of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cytomegalovirus The given intranuclear basophilic inclusions surrounded by a clear halo suggestive of owl’s eye inclusion bodies, characteristically seen in CMV infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sensitive and specific marker of intestinal inflammation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fecal lactoferrin Fecal lactoferrin is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation. It is a marker of inflammatory bowel disease. Fecal calprotectin present in neutrophils and monocytes is another marker of IBD. It correlates well with histologic inflammation, predicts relapse and detects pouchitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man dies due to myocardial infarction. Which of the following stains can be used to see the infarct in the heart while conducting autopsy.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride stain can be used to see the infarct in the heart. The gross histochemical stain imparts a brick-red color to intact, non-infarcted myocardium where lactate dehydrogenase activity is preserved. But because dehydrogenases leak out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 70-year-old comes with complaints of hip pain. An xray of the hip shows lytic lesions and serum calciu m levels are elevated. Bone marrow plasma cells are 42% and the cells seen are given in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Multiple myeloma The given image shows Mott cells which are characteristic of Multiple Myeloma. Multiple Myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with proliferation of plasma cells of a single clone. It is associated with increased osteoclastic activity, hence punched out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A young person with recurrent seasonal conjunctivitis presents with itchiness and watering in the eyes. What is the most likely cell involved in the immediate phase of this condition.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mast cells The above are features of allergic reactions suggest Type 1 Hypersensitivity which is mediated by IgE binding to mast cells. It is triggered by the binding of an antigen to an IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells, which triggers the release of inflammatory mediators. Histamine and leukotrienes are released in the early phase. Late phase is characterised by the recruitment of leukocytes.

questions.text: A lymph node biopsy of a 30-year-old male with cervical lymphadenopathy showed the following picture. The diagnosis is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hodgkin disease In the given picture, Reed Sternberg (RS) cells are seen, which are pathognomonic of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. RS cells have multinucleated or bilobed nucleus with prominent eosinophilic inclusion-like nucleoli.

questions.text: Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Autoimmunity Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of autoimmune origin that attacks the joints. It leads to progressive, non-suppurative inflammatory synovitis. The inflammation progresses to destruct the articular cartilage and ankylosis of the joints.

questions.text: Asbestos exposure may be associated with which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mesothelioma Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis that occurs after 5-10 years of exposure to asbestos. It has 2 varieties- Serpentine and Amphibole type. It affects the basal part of lung causing diffuse peribronchial fibrosis. Asbestosis related diseases include- Mesothelioma, Lung ca, Diffuse pleural fibrosis and pleural effusion.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties. On examination, pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles was noted. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Absent dystrophin The given clinical history is suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). In DMD, Dystrophin protein is absent due to mutation in dystrophin gene mutation. It leads to progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties with characteristic pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles.

questions.text: Following urine microscopy and examination, a child is found to have haematuria and RBC casts in the urine. What is the probable cause for this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) The given clinical findings of nephritic syndrome (hematuria and red cell casts) seen in this child is most likely due to PSGN. PSGN usually occurs following a throat infection by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci. It is characterised by sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension and renal insufficiency.

choices.text: All of the options given below

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of haemolytic anaemia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Decreased haptoglobin In intravascular hemolysis, free hemoglobin released from lysed red cells is bound by haptoglobin, producing a complex that is rapidly cleared by phagocytes. In extravascular hemolysis, some hemoglobin escapes from phagocytes and leads to variable decrease in plasma haptoglobin.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the effect of the mutation causing sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Glutamate by valine at 6th position Sickle cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to point mutation in the 6th position of the beta globin gene, resulting in replacement of glutamate with valine. This leads to the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to polymerisation of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS). The HbS molecules have a tendency to stack into polymers when deoxygenated.

questions.text: Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein is a major component of which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Renal casts Tamm-Horsfall protein (also known as Uromodulin) is the most common protein present in urine and is produced in the thick ascending loop of Henle. It is the most abundant protein in normal human urine. They form the organic matrix of all renal casts. They play a role in the innate immunity in the kidney.

questions.text: What type of cell is shown in the image below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Reed Sternberg cell In the given picture, Reed Sternberg (RS) cells are seen, which are pathognomonic of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. RS cells have multinucleated or bilobed nucleus with prominent eosinophilic inclusion-like nucleoli. Other options- a. Faggot cells are cells with multiple Auer rods clustered together. b. Mott cells are plasma cells with cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russel bodies. They are characteristic of Multiple myeloma. d. Sezary-Lutzner cells are neoplastic T-cells with cerebriform nuclei seen in Mycosis fungoides and Sezary syndrome.

choices.text: Psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells

questions.text: A 40 year old female presents with frequent headaches. Investigation reveals raised intracranial pressure and the presence of dural based tumor. Which of the following histological findings correlate with the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells Meningiomas are benign tumors of adults, attached to the dura that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. The most common cytogenetic abnormality is the loss of chromosome 22 (22q). The lesions contain psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells n histopathological examination. When present in multiple sites, the possibility of Neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered. Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

45 year male presented with Headache. CT shows brain tumor. On HPE psammoma bodies are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
60 year old Female with Solitary Thyroid Nodule. On HPE, cells with pink eosinophilic cytoplasm are observed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The histopathology (HPE) image shows thyroid cells with abundant pink (eosinophilic) cytoplasm, which are characteristic of Hurthle cells, also known as oncocytic cells. These cells are seen in follicular thyroid carcinoma, particularly in its Hurthle cell variant. Hurthle cells are large epithelial cells with granular eosinophilic cytoplasm due to numerous mitochondria. This variant tends to be more aggressive and may show vascular or capsular invasion. The presence of a solitary thyroid nodule in an elderly female and these HPE findings strongly point toward follicular carcinoma. Incorrect Option: A. Medullary Thyroid Cancer Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid arises from parafollicular C cells and often shows amyloid deposits in the stroma on histology. The tumor cells are typically spindle-shaped or polygonal and do not have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Medullary carcinoma is also associated with elevated calcitonin levels, which is not discussed here. Incorrect Option: C. Anaplastic Cancer Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a highly aggressive tumor that typically shows pleomorphic, undifferentiated giant cells or spindle cells with marked nuclear atypia. It lacks the eosinophilic Hurthle cells shown in this image and usually presents in elderly individuals with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. Incorrect Option: D. Papillary Cancer Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid cancer and typically shows Orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies on histology. It is not characterized by abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm as seen in Hurthle cells and usually presents with multifocal disease and lymphatic spread.

65 year old female with breast mass. Microscopic image given. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fibroadenoma. The provided microscopic image displays a benign biphasic tumor characterized by the proliferation of both glandular epithelial and stromal components. A classic feature visible is the intracanalicular pattern, where the proliferating stroma compresses and distorts the ducts into slit-like or elongated structures, as clearly outlined in the image. This distinct histological arrangement is highly characteristic of a fibroadenoma, which is a common benign breast lesion. Malignant conditions like Invasive Ductal Carcinoma or Lobular Breast Cancer would show clear signs of cellular atypia, invasion, and different architectural patterns not present here.

Child presenting with obesity , short stature y muscle weakness , learning disability, Johl propa Chromosome analysis reveals deletion on short &m of chr 15 on paternal side . What is the most likely diagnosis ?
